Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type

Allegation On 7/31/25, a youth was admitted to the ER for unknown reasons.
Upon being discharged, the agency refused to provide the youth
with safe transportation.
Investigation INTERVIEWS
Independent Living (IL) Program Manager was interviewed by
phone on 8/7/2025. She reported having received a phone call on
7/31/2025 from Independent Living (IL) Supervisor who reported
Youth A had been taken to the emergency room by ambulance
due to complaints of feeling nauseous. IL Supervisor called IL
Program Manager back a little later stating that Youth A was being
discharged from the emergency room and she needed a ride
back to the independent living home. IL Program Manager and IL
Supervisor discussed Youth A’s transportation options such as
utilizing the service through the number listed on the back of
Youth A’s Medicaid card, walking, ride share, or riding with her
boyfriend who was with her at the hospital. IL Supervisor called IL
Program Manager a third time stating the hospital staff were not
ok with any of the transportation options suggested by IL
Supervisor. IL Program Manager stated the agency’s independent
living youth have used these methods in the past when being
discharged from the same hospital, so she was unsure why there
were concerns this time. IL Program Manager stated she was told
someone from the hospital drove Youth A back to the independent
living home. She stated Youth A’s boyfriend followed them in his
car and, when they got to the home, Youth A got out of the
hospital staff’s vehicle and got into her boyfriend’s car and left. IL
Program Manager stated she does not know why the hospital did
not allow Youth A to leave the hospital with her boyfriend.
Independent Living (IL) Supervisor was interviewed by phone
on 8/7/2025. She stated, on 7/31/2025, Youth A called an
ambulance and went to the emergency room reporting she had
been having diarrhea and was vomiting for four days. IL
Supervisor stated Youth A was given Zofran, Benadryl, and pain
medication before being discharged from the emergency room. IL
Supervisor stated a hospital staff member called her stating Youth
A was ready for discharge and to return to the independent living
home. IL Supervisor explained Youth A is an independent living
youth and told the hospital staff Youth A had a bus pass, could
call the transportation service number on her Medicaid card, could
use ride share, or she could ride with her boyfriend who was at the
hospital with her. IL Supervisor stated the hospital staff member
stated they were not comfortable releasing Youth A to her
boyfriend, but did not explain why. She has no information to
suggest Youth A’s boyfriend is unsafe or that she cannot be with
2

him. IL Supervisor stated someone from the hospital dropped
Youth A off at the independent living home after which Youth A
went inside, grabbed her purse, then left again. She returned by
curfew at which time staff reported to IL Supervisor that Youth A
seemed fine.
IL Supervisor reported Youth A has been in a detention facility in
Ohio on 8/5/2025 for charges unrelated to this incident. IL
Supervisor stated Youth A will not be returning to the independent
living home as she turns 18 this month and may be going to jail.
Her case was returned to a local MDHHS office for case
management as of 8/5/2025.
Community Health Worker was interviewed by phone on
8/7/2025. She stated Youth A came to the emergency room
reporting abdominal pain which progressed into a migraine. Due
to the medication Youth A was given, the medical providers were
not comfortable leaving Youth A to decide regarding her ride
home so Community Health Worker was called to assist Youth A
with finding transportation back to her independent living home.
She reported having spoken with a staff member at the
independent living home who told her they are not authorized to
provide transportation. The staff member told Community Health
Worker that Youth A lives independently and needs to find a ride
using her resources. Youth A told Community Health Worker she
could walk back home, but Community Health Worker told her that
wouldn’t be allowed. Community Health Worker stated she called
her superior who told her to call the independent living home
again. This time when she called, she spoke with IL Supervisor. IL
Supervisor told Community Health Worker Youth A’s ride options
which included riding the bus or utilizing ride share but would not
come get her. Community Health Worker stated she requested
assistance from the hospital transportation service and waited with
her for several hours until the transporter was available.
Community Health Worker was asked why none of the
transportation options presented by the staff of the independent
living home and IL Supervisor were utilized to which Community
Health Worker responded Youth A’s medical providers did not feel
any of them were appropriate because the medication Youth A
was given made her drowsy and she kept falling asleep. When
asked why Youth A could not ride home with her boyfriend,
Community Health Worker stated her boyfriend was never at the
hospital with Youth A. She stated the medical providers did not
feel it was a safe option to call Youth A’s boyfriend to provide
transportation to Youth A due to the medication making her so
3

drowsy. Community Health Worker did not provide any specific
reasons why this would not have been an appropriate option.
Youth Support Specialist 1 was interviewed by phone on
8/25/202025. She stated she was working at the time Youth A
went to the hospital. She stated Youth A told her she was having a
hard time breathing, was panting, and was sweating. Youth
Support Specialist 1 got a glass of cold water and a cool
washcloth for Youth A, but neither helped. Youth Support
Specialist 1 stated it appeared as if Youth A might be having a
panic attack and was hyperventilating. Youth Support Specialist 1
asked Youth A if she wanted her to call 911 for her and Youth A
stated she did. An ambulance arrived at the home and Youth A
was brought to local children’s hospital. Youth Support Specialist
1 stated she received a call from Community Health Worker later
that day stating Youth A needed a ride home. Youth Support
Specialist 1 called IL Supervisor who gave her the transportation
options for Youth A including using her bus pass, calling ride
share such as Uber, or calling the number on her Medicaid card,
and told Youth Support Specialist 1 she could not leave the home.
Community Health Worker called Youth Support Specialist 1 again
stating Youth A was given medication that made her drowsy so
she could not walk back, and they were not comfortable
discharging her until she secured transportation. Youth Support
Specialist 1 gave the hospital staff the list of transportation options
for Youth A including Youth A’s boyfriend’s phone number. Youth
Support Specialist 1 stated Youth A’s boyfriend was a good
support for Youth A. Youth Support Specialist 1 stated she did not
recall how Youth A was transported back to the home but recalled
speaking with Youth A after she returned about her visit to the
hospital.
DOCUMENTS REVIEWED
• 7/31/2025 After Visit Summary documenting Youth A
reported experiencing abdominal pain, vomiting, and
dizziness for which Youth A was provided information
regarding viral gastroenteritis and was given Benadryl at
1:07pm, Toradol at 1:10pm and Reglan at 1:13pm. She
was also given a prescription for Zofran.
• Rental Agreement and House Rules form signed by Youth
A on 7/17/2025 which has a line to be filled in if any
transportation assistance will be provided by agency staff.
The line on Youth A’s contract was left blank.
4

• Agency Independent Living Guide which outlines the
responsibilities of the agency foster care workers regarding
medical care which includes assisting youth when needed
with transportation to appointments.
Analysis No violation is established as agency staff ensured Youth A had
the appropriate resources to secure a ride home from the hospital,
including transportation provided by Medicaid.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
IV. RECOMMENDATION
Based on investigative findings the facility is in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. It is recommended that the current license status be
continued.
